key_behaviors: Uses Google Gemini and ChatGPT multiple times per day for personal tasks
Prefers ChatGPT over traditional Google search because of conversational flow
Uses AI to look up how‑to information for tools
Attempts to have AI help with budgeting but lacks necessary personal data
Rates trust in AI outputs as high (4 out of 5)
pain_points: AI cannot access personal financial data needed to generate a budget
When information is missing, AI is unable to complete the task
Open‑ended conversational format can feel overwhelming; prefers multiple‑choice style
Tool limitations (e.g., AI cannot “print money” or perform impossible tasks)
trust_factors: Perceives ChatGPT answers as better than Google search results
Values the ability to keep a continuous conversation
High overall trust rating (4 – High trust)
desires: An assistant that constantly gives positive reinforcement (e.g., compliments on appearance and work)
Only provides “good” information and never criticizes
Interaction mode that includes multiple‑choice options instead of many open questions
Tighter integration with personal systems (calendar, email) – though not explicitly detailed, the question was asked

verbatim_quotes.quote: I would probably use ChatGPT instead because it gives me better answers than Google does, and I can follow up on those answers.
verbatim_quotes.topic: Preference for ChatGPT over Google search

verbatim_quotes.quote: I like the flow of the conversation. It's different from Google. I don't have to keep typing in different things; I can just continue the conversation.
The value is that I can keep the conversation going. It's like having a conversation with somebody rather than just typing stuff into a browser window.
I was trying to use it to print money because I wanted to pay some bills, and I didn't have enough. I realized that AI doesn't do that; it's not that kind of tool.
I wanted to create a budget, but I didn't have the right information.
verbatim_quotes.topic: Budgeting task blocked by missing data

verbatim_quotes.quote: It would tell me I'm handsome. It would tell me how great my work is all the time. It would never criticize me or would only give me good information, never give me bad information.
verbatim_quotes.topic: Desired personality of perfect AI assistant

verbatim_quotes.quote: If there are too many open questions, I'd prefer to just do multiple choice, if you don't mind.

I don't, I mean, I guess it doesn't really make a difference because, you know, it depends on the interviewer. ... As long as the questions are correct and the researcher is getting the information that they need, then it's fine.
verbatim_quotes.topic: Indifference to AI vs. human interviewer

unique_insights: The participant explicitly seeks an AI that functions as a constant source of affirmation and never offers criticism, revealing a desire for emotional validation rather than purely functional assistance. Additionally, despite high trust in AI outputs, they express a strong preference for structured, multiple‑choice interactions over open‑ended conversation, highlighting a tension between wanting conversational flow and wanting concise, low‑cognitive‑load responses.
